results.title: An Artist looks at churches
results.creator_credit: John Taylor, Edgar H. Anstey and British Transport Films
results.brief_description: Out of 20,000 churches in Britain the artist John Piper, selects one from each century from Norman times to the present day. He reveals their riches of architecture, decoration, carving, sculpture and stained glass.
results.creator_credit_for_label: John Taylor, Edgar H. Anstey and British Transport Films

results.title: Artist at work: five British sculptors work and talk (TEFC)
results.creator_credit: Warren Forma and Forma Arts Associates
results.brief_description: Shows five British sculptors as they work in their studios and discuss their achievements: Barbara Hepworth, who made the centerpiece for the exterior circle of the United Nations Headquarters in New York; Kenneth Armitage, who made “Mouton sun” for Chateau Mouton Rothschild; Lyn Chadwick, who won first prize in 1959 at Padua; Reg Butler, who won grand prize for his monument of the unknown political prisoner in 1953; Henry Moore, who completed the centerpieces for the Lincoln Centre for the Performing Arts in New York.

results.title: Jacques Lipchitz: master sculptor
results.creator_credit: Bert Van Bork and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: A colour portrait of one of the foremost pioneers in modern art. Born in Lithuania, Jacques Lipchitz now lives in New York. Some of his works are inspired by the past while others are a reflection of present times. As he works in his studio on a portrait of the late President Kennedy, Lipchitz adds his own insight, his own knowledge about the man, and his own interpretation of the times.

results.title: The Artisan
results.brief_description: A film without narration, following a skilled artisan hand a guitar using traditional woodworking methods, showing all the stages of construction.

results.title: Artificial respiration by the H N Method
results.creator_credit: Svend Aage Lorentz and Danish Red Cross
results.brief_description: This film demonstrates the method of artificial respiration developed by Holger Nielson. The two basic movements of each cycle are the back pressure and arm lift. Application for adults is demonstrated and the modifications necessary for use on children are also shown.

results.title: Artificial breeding of dairy cattle
results.creator_credit: Jack Gardiner, John Kingsford-Smith and Kingcroft Productions
results.brief_description: Demonstrates artificial insemination of dairy cattle at the Aberdeen Breeding Station, N.S.W., and shows how the productive capacity of an average herd can be improved, through careful selection of bulls, handling of cattle, collection and testing of semen, including the construction of an artificial vagina, and insemination of cows. Mentions the advantages of the artificial breeding of dairy cattle.

results.title: Article 55
results.creator_credit: Leo Seltzer and Department of Public Information of the United Nations
results.brief_description: Article 55 of the United Nations Charter provides for the promotion of economic and social progress and development. The film shows how a mission to Bolivia was established, and pictures the complete problem which faces them. Shows also how Bolivia suffers with other undeveloped countries the burdens of ill health, of relying on depression prone primary exports, and of lacking the fundamental facilities which attract overseas capital.

results.title: Arthur Penn: the director during the filming of "Little Big Man"
results.creator_credit: Elliott Erwitt and Elliott Erwitt Enterprises
results.brief_description: A portrait of the director Arthur Penn at work on the film ‘Little Big Man’. Using extracts from the film and footage shot behind-the-scene this film illustrates the two main problems involved in the production of a film, the relationship between director and star and the insertion of the director’s personal convictions into his film.
results.title_for_label: Arthur Penn: the director during the filming of “Little Big Man”

results.title: Arthropods: insects and their relatives
results.brief_description: This film examines the major physical characteristics which are used to identify arthropods. It compares and studies examples from each of the four main classifications - myriapods, insects, arachnids and crustaceans - and describes their common characteristics, their environments, and the ways in which they are helpful and harmful. Uses magnified close-ups and detailed anatomical drawings. No other credits available.

results.title: Arthropods: animal life
results.creator_credit: Dennis Sawyer and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: The joint-legged animals and the structural and functional characteristics of animals in the phylum Arthropoda; examples from each of the five classes, and their evolutionary development. Metamorphosis and moulting processes are illustrated using photomicrography and time-lapse photography. The economic importance of this class of animals is also discussed.
